choices.text: Substance P

questions.text: Which neurotransmitter is responsible for anterograde dilatation of the small intestine?(NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. VIP

 

Explanation

 

VIP is responsible for anterograde dilatation of the small intestine.

 

During peristalsis, segment of intestine behind the bolus contracts while segment in front of it relaxes.

 

Cholinergic neurons in the anterograde direction produce NO and VIP which cause relaxes the segment of the intestine in front of the bolus.

 

Cholinergic neurons in the retrograde direction produce substance P and acetylcholine which contracts the segment of the intestine behind the bolus.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Acetylcholine: Incorrect as acetylcholine is involved in the contraction of the intestinal segment behind the bolus, not in the dilatation.

 

Option C. Substance P: Incorrect because it also contributes to the contraction of the intestinal muscles behind the bolus.

 

Option D. Serotonin: Incorrect as serotonin is involved in overall motility and secretion within the gut but not specifically in anterograde dilatation as described here.

 

Educational Objective:

 

VIP is crucial for the anterograde dilatation of the small intestine, promoting the relaxation of the intestinal segment ahead of the bolus during peristalsis, thereby facilitating the forward movement of intestinal contents.

questions.text: A patient presented with clinical features of ataxia and incoordination. This is due to thrombosis of which artery? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Superior cerebellar

 

  • Thrombosis of the superior cerebellar artery causes cerebellar lesion which presents with ataxia and incoordination.
  • The superior cerebellar artery (SCA) is a branch of the basilar artery and supplies the superior surface of the cerebellum, the roof nuclei, and parts of the midbrain.
  • When there is a thrombosis (formation of a blood clot) in the SCA, the blood supply to these areas is disrupted, which can cause various neurological symptoms such as ataxia, incoordination, and dizziness.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Posterior cerebral artery (PCA): It supplies blood to the occipital lobe, parts of the temporal lobe, and the inferomedial portion of the thalamus.

 

  • Thrombosis of the PCA can lead to:
    • Contralateral homonymous hemianopia (loss of half of the field of vision in both eyes)
    • Memory impairment (if it affects the hippocampus)
    • Alexia without agraphia (an inability to read without an inability to write) if the dominant hemisphere is involved.

 

Option B. Middle cerebral artery (MCA): It supplies blood to the majority of the outer convex brain surface, including the frontal, parietal, and superior temporal lobes.

 

  • Thrombosis of the MCA can lead to:
    • Contralateral hemiparesis and sensory loss (mainly of the face and upper limb)
    • If the dominant hemisphere (typically the left in right-handed individuals) is affected, expressive aphasia can occur.
    • If the non-dominant hemisphere is involved, spatial neglect might be observed.

 

Option C. Internal carotid artery (ICA): It does not give off any significant branches in its cervical or petrous portions. Its terminal branches in the brain are the MCA and ACA (anterior cerebral artery). Thrombosis of the ICA can compromise blood flow to both the ACA and MCA territories, leading to a combination of the symptoms associated with obstruction of those arteries.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Blood supply of cerebellum:

 

  • Superior cerebellar artery
  • Posterior inferior cerebellar artery
  • Anterior inferior cerebellar artery

 

Common symptoms of cerebellar lesions:

questions.text: Which of the following is not used for induction of anesthesia in pediatric patients? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Desflurane

 

  • Desflurane is a highly pungent gas, and its use for inhalational induction can lead to airway irritation, coughing, breath-holding, and even laryngospasm, especially in pediatric patients.
  • Therefore, desflurane is not typically used as an induction agent.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Halothane: Due to its pleasant odor and rapid onset, Halothane was historically a popular choice for inhalational induction in children. However, concerns regarding hepatotoxicity and arrhythmias have reduced its usage in modern practice.

 

Option B. Sevoflurane: Sevoflurane is one of the most commonly used agents for inhalational induction in pediatric patients due to its non-irritating nature and rapid kinetics.

 

Option D. Nitrous Oxide: Nitrous oxide is often used as an adjunct to other inhalational anesthetics for both induction and maintenance of anesthesia. It has a rapid onset and is generally well-tolerated by pediatric patients. It can be used for inhalational induction, especially in combination with more potent agents like sevoflurane.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Desflurane is not typically used for the induction of anesthesia in pediatric patients due to its pungent nature, which can cause significant airway irritation and laryngospasm.

questions.text: An 11-year-old boy was brought to the pediatric OPD with multiple abscesses over his face, chest, and back. The child has a history of recurrent respiratory infections. On examination, he has atopic excoriating skin and multiple cold abscesses on his back. What is the most probable diagnosis? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Hyper IgE syndrome

 

The clinical presentation of the boy with recurrent skin and respiratory infections, atopic excoriating skin, and notably, cold abscesses, strongly points towards Hyper IgE syndrome, also known as Job's syndrome. This condition is characterized by:

 

  • High levels of IgE: Elevated IgE is a hallmark of the syndrome and contributes to the immune dysregulation seen in these patients.
  • Recurrent infections: Due to defects in immune regulation, particularly affecting the response of neutrophils and other immune cells.
  • Dermatologic issues: Such as eczema and atopic dermatitis are common and often severe in these patients.
  • Genetic background: Hyper IgE syndrome is commonly caused by mutations in the STAT3 gene, which is critical for many aspects of immune system function, including the development and function of neutrophils.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hyper IgM syndrome: Incorrect, characterized by elevated levels of IgM with low levels of other immunoglobulins, leading to a susceptibility to infections. It does not typically present with high IgE levels or eczema.

 

Option B. Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome: Incorrect, this is a condition that affects blood cells and immune response, characterized by thrombocytopenia, eczema, and recurrent infections; however, it does not typically involve high levels of IgE or cold abscesses.

 

Option D. Carcinoid syndrome: Incorrect, typically presents with symptoms caused by secreted hormones, such as flushing, diarrhea, and heart valve problems, which are unrelated to the immune dysfunction seen in this patient.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hyper IgE syndrome should be considered in patients presenting with a combination of high IgE levels, recurrent skin and respiratory infections, and dermatologic issues such as eczema. Managing this condition often involves addressing the skin care comprehensively and preventing infections through vigilant monitoring and appropriate use of antibiotics.

choices.text: Attached to the inner border of 2nd rib
Attached with transverse process of C7

questions.text: Which among the following statement is incorrect regarding Sibson’s fascia? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Attached to the inner border of 2nd rib

 

Sibson's fascia is joined to the first rib's inner border, not the second rib.

 

Sibson's fascia (suprapleural membrane)

 

  • Covers the apical portion of the lung and acts as a dividing line between the lower neck and the thorax.
  • It is attached to the inner border of the 1st rib and posteriorly to the anterior border of the transverse process of the C7 vertebra.
  • It is strengthened by a few spreading muscular fibers derived from the scalene muscles.
  • The subclavian vessels lie on top of it.

 

Clinical significance

 

  • The suprapleural membrane's function is to protect the apex of the lung (the part that extends outside the rib cage) and the cervical fascia. This aids in resisting intrathoracic pressure changes, preventing neck inflation and deflation during expiration and inspiration, and also providing rigidity to the thoracic inlet.
  • Herniation of the cervical fascia may result due to injury to suprapleural membrane.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Covers apical part of lung (Correct): Sibson's fascia covers the apical (uppermost) part of the lung and helps separate the cervical pleura from the surrounding structures.

 

Option C. Attached with transverse process of C7 (Correct): Sibson's fascia is posteriorly attached with the tip of the transverse process of C7.

 

Option D. Vessels pass above the fascia (Correct): Blood vessels, including the subclavian vessels, pass above Sibson's fascia as they enter and exit the thoracic cavity. This fascia serves as a landmark for the placement of central venous catheters, as it delineates the boundary between the cervical and thoracic regions.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Sibson's fascia is not directly attached to the inner border of the 2nd rib. Instead, it is associated with the cervical pleura and extends superiorly to attach to the transverse process of the 7th cervical (C7) vertebra. It forms the outer boundary of the cervicothoracic (suprapleural) space.

questions.text: Which of the following Carbapenems has highest risk of causing seizures? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Imipenem

 

  • Imipenem is a Carbapenem that has a maximum risk of causing seizures , hence it is contraindicated in epileptic patients.
  • Imipenem excretion is primarily renal, so dosage adjustments are required to avoid seizures in patients with renal failure.

 

Other Options

 

Option A. Meropenem: Meropenem has a lower risk of inducing seizures compared to imipenem, making it a safer alternative for patients with a history of seizures or those at higher risk.

 

Option C. Ertapenem: Ertapenem is also associated with a lower risk of seizures compared to imipenem and is used in various infections but is less effective against Pseudomonas aeruginosa and Acinetobacter species.

 

Option D. Doripenem: Doripenem, like meropenem and ertapenem, has a lower seizure risk compared to imipenem and is used in treating complex bacterial infections.

 

Educational Objective

 

  • Imipenem carries the highest risk of inducing seizures among the carbapenem antibiotics, particularly in patients with renal impairment or a history of epilepsy. Proper dosage adjustments and careful monitoring are essential to minimize this risk.

questions.text: Which of these disorders was earlier known as minimal brain dysfunction?  (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Attention deficit/hyperactivity disorder

 

Attention deficit/hyperactivity disorder (ADHD) was earlier referred to as minimal brain dysfunction. ADHD is characterized by symptoms of inattention, hyperactivity, and impulsivity.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Dyslexia is a specific learning disorder that affects reading, despite normal intelligence. It is characterized by difficulties with accurate and/or fluent word recognition and by poor spelling and decoding abilities.

 

Option C. Mental sub normality is an outdated term, previously used to describe intellectual disabilities or developmental delays.

 

Option D. Oligophrenia is an old term that was used to describe intellectual disability or mental retardation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

ADHD, formerly known as minimal brain dysfunction, is characterized by symptoms of inattention and/or hyperactivity-impulsivity. Diagnosis requires symptoms before age 12 in multiple settings. Treatment commonly involves stimulant medications and behavioral therapy.

 

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page No 1171.

questions.text: Which of the following is lined by simple squamous epithelium? (NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer. A) Loop of Henle

 

Explanation: 

                                   

Loop of Henle is lined by simple squamous epithelium. This specialized thin epithelium facilitates passive diffusion and reabsorption of water and electrolytes. The flattened cells with their minimal thickness are perfectly suited for the Loop of Henle's function in the renal tubular system, allowing efficient transport across the epithelial layer.

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option B. Proximal convoluted tubule (PCT) - PCT is lined by simple cuboidal epithelium with a prominent brush border. These cuboidal cells have numerous microvilli that increase surface area for active reabsorption of filtered substances.
  • Option C. Distal tubule - Distal convoluted tubule (DCT) is lined by simple cuboidal epithelium. These cells have fewer microvilli than PCT cells but contain numerous mitochondria to support active transport processes.
  • Option D. Collecting duct - Collecting ducts are lined by simple cuboidal epithelium. In some regions, particularly deeper parts, the epithelium may become columnar, but it is never squamous.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Simple squamous epithelium is found in areas requiring rapid transport, diffusion, or filtration such as the Loop of Henle, alveoli of lungs, and endothelium of blood vessels due to its thin, flattened morphology that facilitates these functions.

questions.text: Which of the following helminthic infections that is commonly transmitted by soil, is characterized by the egg in stool as shown in the image below? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Trichuris trichiura

 

The given image shows the egg of Trichuris trichiura (whipworm).

 

The characteristic features of whipworm eggs are:

 

  • ﻿﻿Eggs are barrel-shaped in the middle with a projecting mucus plug at each pole containing an unsegmented ovum. The plugs are colorless.
  • ﻿﻿They float in the saturated salt solution.
  • ﻿﻿It has a triple shell, the outermost layer of which is stained brown.

 

They are commonly transmitted by soil. The eggs passed in the stool are unembryonated. Microscopic identification of the eggs in a stool specimen is diagnostic of whipworm infection.

 

In moderate infections of 20 adult worms or less, the worms are confined to the caecum and ascending colon. The symptoms include epigastric and lower abdominal pain, diarrhea (rarely bloody), vomiting, flatulence and distention, weight loss, and increased blood and iron loss.

 

In heavy infections of 200 adult worms or more (trichuriasis dysentery syndrome), the worms are in the distal colon and rectum. The symptoms include bloody diarrhea with profuse mucus, abdominal pain, tenesmus, weight loss leading to cachexia, severe anemia, and rectal prolapse. On examination, clubbing may be present. Blood investigations may show moderate eosinophilia.

 

Chronic infection leads to growth retardation and nutritional deficiencies. Around 0.005 ml of blood is lost per day per worm. In heavy infections, as much as 4 to 5 ml can be lost per day per worm.

 

Treatment is mebendazole or albendazole.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Ancylostoma duodenale: Causes hookworm infection, characterized by eggs that are oval and thin-shelled, different from the barrel-shaped eggs of whipworm.

 

Option C. Necator americanus: Another species of hookworm with similar egg morphology to Ancylostoma duodenale.

 

Option D. Ascaris lumbricoides: Causes ascariasis and is characterized by larger, oval, and thick-shelled eggs, distinct from the eggs of whipworm.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Recognizing the distinctive egg morphology of Trichuris trichiura in stool samples is crucial for diagnosing whipworm infection. Proper sanitation and hygiene are key in preventing soil-transmitted helminth infections, and treatment involves specific antihelminthic medications to reduce the worm burden and alleviate symptoms.

questions.text: Which of the following inhibits the synthesis of glucocorticoid?(NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Metyrapone

 

Metyrapone is a drug that inhibits the synthesis of glucocorticoids by blocking the enzyme 11β-hydroxylase. This enzyme is crucial for the final step in the biosynthesis of cortisol in the adrenal cortex. By inhibiting this enzyme, metyrapone reduces the production of cortisol and is used in the diagnosis and management of Cushing's syndrome.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Mifepristone: Mifepristone is an anti-progestogen and also acts as a glucocorticoid receptor antagonist but does not inhibit the synthesis of glucocorticoids.

 

Option B. Flutamide: Flutamide is an androgen receptor antagonist used primarily in the treatment of prostate cancer. It does not affect glucocorticoid synthesis.

 

Option C. Finasteride: Finasteride is a 5-α reductase inhibitor used in the treatment of benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH) and androgenic alopecia. It inhibits the conversion of testosterone to dihydrotestosterone (DHT) and has no effect on glucocorticoid synthesis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Mifepristone is an Anti-Progestogen.

 

Flutamide is an androgen receptor antagonist.

 

Finasteride is a 5-α Reductase inhibitor.

 

Metyrapone is enzyme 11ß-hydroxylase inhibitor.

questions.text: Following complete ileal and partial jejunal resection, the patient is most likely to have?(NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Vitamin B12 deficiency

 

After complete ileal and partial jejunal resection, the patient is likely to have vitamin B12 deficiency.

 

Normal gastric secretions contain a glycoprotein called intrinsic factor, secreted by the same parietal cells that secrete hydrochloric acid. Intrinsic factor must be present for adequate absorption of vitamin B12 from the ileum. That is, intrinsic factor combines with vitamin B12 in the stomach and protects it from being digested and destroyed as it passes into the small intestine. Then, when the intrinsic factor–vitamin B12 complex reaches the terminal ileum, the intrinsic factor binds with receptors on the ileal epithelial surface. This in turn makes it possible for the vitamin B12 to be absorbed

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Folic acid deficiency: Incorrect as the primary site for folate absorption is the jejunum. While partial jejunal resection could impact folate absorption, the redundancy in folate absorption along the small intestine generally compensates unless the resection is extensive.

 

Option C. Gastric ulcer: Incorrect because gastric ulcers are typically related to factors affecting the stomach lining, such as Helicobacter pylori infection or NSAID use, and are not directly caused by resections of the ileum or jejunum.

 

Option D. Constipation: Incorrect as constipation is more commonly associated with colonic function disruptions or changes in diet following gastrointestinal surgery, not specifically related to the ileum or jejunum resections which would more likely impact diarrhea due to reduced absorption capacities.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The resection of the terminal ileum specifically compromises vitamin B12 absorption due to the loss of the primary site where the vitamin B12-intrinsic factor complex is absorbed. This can lead to significant clinical issues related to vitamin B12 deficiency, such as anemia and neurological disturbances, unless managed with appropriate supplementation.

 

Major Sites of Absorption of Hematopoietic Factors

 

  • Iron is absorbed in duodenum and upper jejunum
  • Folate is absorbed in jejunum
  • Vitamin B12 is absorbed in terminal Ileum

choices.text: Iso-volumetric contraction
Slow filling at end of diastole
End of systole
Start of diastole

questions.text: 'c' wave in JVP is seen in which phase of cardiac cycle? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Iso-volumetric contraction

 

Explanation

 

'c' waves are produced by bulging of the tricuspid valve into the right atrium during the Iso-volumetric contraction of the right ventricle.

 

The isovolumetric contraction phase is characterized by a closed tricuspid valve and a still-closed pulmonary valve, which causes the pressure in the ventricle to rise rapidly without changing its volume.

 

 

Fig: Intra-arterial pressure changes during cardiac cycle. a, c, v= Positive wave x, x1, y= Negative waves

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Slow filling at end of diastole: Incorrect because this phase involves the heart filling with blood, not contracting.

 

Option C. End of systole: Incorrect as this phase corresponds to the onset of ventricular relaxation, not contraction.

 

Option D. Start of diastole: Incorrect because the start of diastole is marked by ventricular relaxation and opening of the atrioventricular valves for ventricular filling, not contraction.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Which Reflex is responsible for tachycardia during right atrial distension? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Bainbridge reflex

 

Explanation

 

Bainbridge reflex is a cardioaccelerator reflex that increases the heart rate when venous return is increased. Since this reflex arises from right atrium, it is also called right atrial reflex.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. J Reflex: Apnea followed by rapid breathing, bradycardia, and hypotension due to J receptor (C-receptor, juxta-pulmonary capillary receptor) stimulation.

 

Option B. Cushing Reflex: Incorrect because the Cushing reflex involves increased blood pressure, bradycardia, and respiratory depression in response to increased intracranial pressure, not right atrial distension.

 

Option C. Bezold-Jarisch Reflex: Bezold-Jarisch reflex is the reflex characterized by bradycardia and hypotension, caused by stimulation of chemoreceptors present in the wall of left ventricles by substances such as alkaloids. It is also called coronary chemoreflex. Vagal fibers form the afferent and efferent pathways of this reflex.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Bainbridge reflex is responsible for inducing tachycardia in response to right atrial distension. It serves to adjust heart rate upward when venous return to the heart increases, ensuring optimal cardiac output and circulation efficiency.

questions.text: A patient underwent a coronary bypass graft with the great saphenous vein. The patient now complains of paresthesia and sensory loss over the medial aspect of the leg and foot. Which of the following nerves is most likely to be involved?(NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Saphenous nerve

 

  • The patient's symptoms of paresthesia and sensory loss over the medial aspect of the leg and foot indicate possible damage to the saphenous nerve, which can occur during a venous cutdown procedure to access the great saphenous vein for coronary bypass graft.
  • The saphenous nerve is a major cutaneous branch of the femoral nerve and is the longest nerve in the body.
  • After arising from the posterior division of the femoral nerve, it enters and exits the adductor canal before piercing the fascia lata between the gracilis and sartorius muscles.
  • From there, it runs along the medial border of the tibia alongside the great saphenous vein and supplies sensation to the skin over the patella, knee, leg, and foot, up to the first metatarsophalangeal joint.
  • During a venous cutdown procedure, injury to the saphenous nerve is common due to its proximity to the great saphenous vein.
  • The resulting sensory loss typically affects the medial aspect of the knee, leg, and foot.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Superficial Peroneal Nerve: This nerve originates from the common peroneal nerve (a branch of the sciatic nerve). It runs in the lateral compartment of the leg.

 

  • Sensory Distribution: Supplies sensation to the dorsum (top) of the foot and a small area over the lateral aspect of the lower leg.
  • Clinical Manifestation of Injury: Loss of sensation in its sensory distribution and potential weakness in eversion of the foot.

 

Option C. Femoral Nerve: Arises from the lumbar plexus (L2-L4).

 

  • Motor Functions: It supplies the anterior compartment muscles of the thigh which are primarily responsible for hip flexion and knee extension.
  • Sensory Distribution: Over the anterior thigh and medial aspect of the leg (via the saphenous nerve, its branch).
  • Clinical Manifestation of Injury: Weakness in hip flexion and knee extension along with sensory loss over its distribution.

 

Option D. Sural Nerve: This nerve is formed by branches from both the tibial and common peroneal nerves. It runs along the posterior and then lateral side of the calf.

 

  • Sensory Distribution: Supplies the posterolateral aspect of the leg and the lateral side of the foot.
  • Clinical Manifestation of Injury: Loss of sensation in its sensory distribution.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: What is the maximum period of voluntary self-admission under the Mental Healthcare Act 2017?(NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 30 days

 

Under the Mental Healthcare Act 2017 of India, a person with a mental illness can voluntarily admit themselves to a mental health establishment. The maximum duration for such voluntary admission is up to 30 days. If extended care is needed beyond this period, a fresh admission process is required.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Under the Mental Healthcare Act 2017 in India, a person with a mental illness can voluntarily admit themselves to a mental health establishment for a maximum period of 30 days.

 

Reference: Forensic Psychiatry in India, Interface of Indian laws and mental health, 27-28.

choices.text: Increased Fat content of the cells

questions.text: What is the definition of hypertrophy?  (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B. Increased in size of cells

 

Explanation:

 

Hypertrophy refers specifically to an increase in the size of existing cells without an increase in cell number. From Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology, this is confirmed when discussing muscle adaptations: "Increased activity can lead to muscle cell hypertrophy, which allows for increase in contractile strength." The key characteristic of hypertrophy is the enlargement of individual cells, not their multiplication.

 

Other Options: 

 

  • Option a. Increased Fat content of the cells - This describes lipid accumulation within cells, which is a different cellular change unrelated to hypertrophy. Hypertrophy involves growth of functional cellular components, not fat storage.
  • Option c. Increase in number of cells  - This defines hyperplasia, not hypertrophy. Hyperplasia involves cell multiplication through division, whereas hypertrophy involves enlargement of existing cells.
  • Option d. None of the above - This is incorrect since option b correctly defines hypertrophy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hypertrophy is the increase in cell size that enhances functional capacity without cell multiplication, as observed in skeletal muscle adaptation to increased workload.

questions.text: The Confusion Assessment Method (CAM) is primarily used to assess which of the following conditions? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Delirium

 

The Confusion Assessment Method (often referred to as CAM) is a diagnostic tool specifically designed to identify delirium.

 

CAM is used primarily for the detection of delirium, especially in hospitalized or elderly patients. It evaluates features like acute onset and fluctuating course, inattention, disorganized thinking, and altered level of consciousness.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Dementia: While CAM can help differentiate delirium from dementia, it is not specifically designed for the diagnosis of dementia.

 

Option C. Schizophrenia: CAM is not used in the diagnosis or assessment of schizophrenia.

 

Option D. Depression: CAM is not used in the diagnosis or assessment of depression.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

The Confusion Assessment Method (CAM) is a tool specifically developed to detect delirium. Bedside examinations such as mini mental status examination (MMSE) are used to provide a measure of cognitive impairment.

 

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page No 701.

questions.text: What is the likely diagnosis from the image given below? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Pterygium

 

The likely diagnosis, based on the above image, is pterygium.

  • Pterygium is a subconjunctival fibrovascular tissue encroaching the cornea.
  • It is a wing-shaped fold of conjunctiva encroaching upon the cornea from either side within the interpalpebral fissure.
  • It is more common in people living in hot climates, and a response to prolonged effect of environmental factors such as exposure to sun (ultraviolet rays), dry heat, high wind and abundance of dust.

 

Clinical features:

  • It is more common in elderly males doing outdoor work.
  • It may be unilateral or bilateral.
  • It presents as a triangular fold of conjunctiva encroaching the cornea in the area of palpebral aperture, usually on the nasal side but may also occur on the temporal side.
  • Deposition of iron seen sometimes in corneal epithelium anterior to advancing head of pterygium is called stocker's line.
  • Mostly asymptomatic.
  • Irritation and grittiness are caused by a dellen – localized drying of tear film.
  • Cosmesis may be a significant problem.
  • Visual disturbances occur when it encroaches the pupillary area or due to corneal astigmatism induced due to fibrosis in the regressive stage.
  • Diplopia may occur due to limitation of ocular movements.
  • PARTS OF A PTERYGIUM:

 

A fully developed pterygium consists of three parts

  1. Head (apical part present on the cornea),
  2. Neck (limbal part), and
  3. Body (scleral part) extending between limbus and the canthus.

 

Differences between pterygium and pseudopterygium

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pinguecula: A yellowish, benign growth on the conjunctiva that does not encroach onto the cornea.

 

Option B. Concretions: Small, yellowish-white deposits on the conjunctiva, often associated with chronic conjunctivitis.

 

Option D. Bitot's spots: Foamy, whitish lesions on the conjunctiva, typically associated with vitamin A deficiency.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pterygium is characterized by a wing-shaped fold of conjunctiva encroaching upon the cornea, commonly seen in people exposed to prolonged environmental factors like UV rays and dust. The treatment includes surgical removal and techniques to prevent recurrence.

questions.text: 100-day glaucoma is seen in which of the following conditions? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Central retinal vein occlusion

 

  • Neovascular glaucoma (NVG) is also known as "90-" or "100-day glaucoma" due to its typical development 3 months after the onset of Central Retinal Vein Occlusion (CRVO).
  • NVG results from the occlusion of the central retinal vein, causing significant retinal ischemia and venous stasis.
  • Recurrent hemorrhages are common, and neovascularization of the retina and optic disc develop.
  • The retina undergoes pigmentary and atrophic changes.
  • NVG occurs in three stages:
    1. Pre-glaucomatous stage - stage of rubeosis iridis i.e. neovascularisation on the surface of the iris.
    2. Open-angle glaucoma stage - due to the formation of a pretrabecular neovascular membrane.
    3. Secondary angle closure glaucoma— due to goniosynechiae resulting from contracture of the neovascular membrane (zipper-angle closure).

 

 

  • Treatment of NVG is usually frustrating.
    • Pan-retinal photocoagulation may be carried out to prevent further neovascularization.
    • Medical therapy and conventional filtration surgery are usually not effective in controlling the IOP.
    • Artificial filtration shunt (valved/unvalved) may control the IOP.
  • Serious complications of central retinal vein occlusion are cystoid degeneration of the macula, optic atrophy, and hemorrhagic or neovascular glaucoma.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Eale’s disease: Eales disease, also known as "primary retinal periphlebitis" or "periphlebitis retinae," is a rare inflammatory disorder that primarily affects the blood vessels in the retina of the eye. It was first described by the British ophthalmologist Henry Eales in 1880, and the condition was subsequently named after him.

 

Eales disease typically occurs in young adults, often males, and is more prevalent in certain regions, including India. The exact cause of Eales disease is not well understood, but it is believed to have an immunological basis. Some theories suggest that it may be related to immune system dysfunction, possibly triggered by an underlying infection or other factors.

 

The main features of Eales disease include:

 

  1. Retinal Vasculitis: Inflammation of the small blood vessels (veins) in the retina. This can lead to retinal hemorrhages, exudates, and swelling, which can affect vision.
  2. Neovascularization: New, abnormal blood vessels may develop as a response to the damaged retinal vessels. These abnormal vessels can be fragile and prone to bleeding, leading to further vision problems.
  3. Vitreous Hemorrhage:
  4. Retinal Detachment: In some cases, Eales disease can lead to tractional retinal detachment.

 

The symptoms of Eales disease can vary and may include blurred vision, floaters, and reduced visual acuity. Diagnosis is typically made through a thorough clinical examination, which may include the use of imaging techniques like fundus fluorescein angiography to visualize the areas of capillary non-perfusion, leakage (suggestive of neovascularisation or macular edema).

 

The treatment of Eales disease aims to control inflammation, prevent or treat complications, and preserve or improve vision. Treatment options may include systemic or local corticosteroids to reduce inflammation and macular edema, intravitreal Anti VEGF injection for macular edema, laser photocoagulation therapy to target abnormal blood vessels, and in some cases, surgical intervention (pars plana vitrectomy) to address complications like retinal detachment and vitreous haemorrhage. The specific treatment plan will depend on the severity of the disease and the individual patient's needs.

 

It's important for individuals with Eales disease to receive ongoing care and follow-up with an ophthalmologist to monitor their condition and manage any potential complications. Causative association with tuberculosis is present and patient needs to be evaluated for TB and AKT may be initiated where indicated.

 

Option C. Central retinal artery occlusion (CRAO) is a medical condition that occurs when the central retinal artery becomes blocked or narrowed. This blockage results in a sudden and severe loss of vision in the affected eye. CRAO is considered a medical emergency because it can lead to permanent vision loss if not treated promptly.

 

Common causes and risk factors of central retinal artery occlusion include:

 

  1. Atherosclerosis: The most common cause of CRAO is atherosclerosis.
  2. Embolism:
  3. Giant cell arteritis: This is a condition in which the arteries, including the central retinal artery, become inflamed. It primarily affects older individuals and can result in CRAO. GCA is an emergency requiring prompt initiation of systemic steroids to prevent the fellow eye from developing CRAO.
  4. Vasculitis: Occlusive inflammation of the blood vessels can lead to occlusion of the central retinal artery.

 

Symptoms of central retinal artery occlusion may include:

 

  1. Sudden, painless, and severe vision loss in one eye.
  2. The affected eye may appear pale or whitened (retinal pallor).
  3. RAPD.
  4. Cherry-red spot: Due to the contrast between the well-oxygenated macula and the poorly oxygenated surrounding retina.

 

Treatment options may include:

 

  1. Ocular massage: to dislodge the embolus causing the blockage.
  2. Hyperbaric oxygen therapy: Breathing pure oxygen in a pressurized chamber can increase oxygen delivery to the retina and may be considered in some cases.
  3. Carbogen inhalation therapy or rebreathing into a paper bag – Resultant hypercarbemia causes vasodilation which may help to dislodge the embolus and restore blood flow.
  4. Reducing intraocular pressure – by means of Anterior Chamber paracentesis or systemic acetazolamide.
  5. Surgical intervention: Optic Nerve Sheath fenestration surgery.
  6. Thrombolytic therapy: In some situations, clot-dissolving medications may be used.

 

Option D. Steroid-induced glaucoma:

 

  • Description: Glaucoma resulting from prolonged use of corticosteroids.
  • Mechanism: Steroids can increase IOP by reducing the outflow of aqueous humor.
  • Symptoms: Gradual loss of peripheral vision, halos around lights, headache, eye pain.
  • Treatment: Reducing or discontinuing steroid use, using IOP-lowering medications.

  • Note: Steroid-induced glaucoma is not associated with neovascularization or termed as 100-day glaucoma.

     

Educational Objective:

 

Neovascular glaucoma, known as "100-day glaucoma," typically develops about three months after the onset of Central Retinal Vein Occlusion (CRVO) due to significant retinal ischemia and venous stasis leading to neovascularization.

questions.text: Respiratory distress syndrome is due to defect in which of the following cell?(NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Type 2 pneumocytes

 

One of the most characteristic findings in respiratory distress syndrome is failure of the respiratory epithelium to secrete adequate quantities of surfactant, a substance normally secreted into the alveoli that decreases the surface tension of the alveolar fluid, therefore allowing the alveoli to open easily during inspiration.

 

The surfactant-secreting cells are type II alveolar epithelial cells.

 

Production of the surfactant begins by week 20-24. It appears in the amniotic fluid between 28 and 32 weeks of gestation. Mature levels of the pulmonary surfactant are present usually after 35 weeks of gestation.

 

Antenatal corticosteroids are given to increase production of surfactant.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Type 1 pneumocytes: Incorrect because although Type 1 pneumocytes cover a large surface area of the alveoli and are involved in the gas exchange process, they do not produce surfactant. The defect in Type 1 pneumocytes generally leads to issues with the structural integrity of the alveolar walls, not surfactant deficiency.

 

Option C. Alveolar capillary endothelial cells: Incorrect as these cells line the alveolar capillaries and are involved in the blood-air barrier for gas exchange. Defects in these cells can lead to issues like pulmonary edema but are not directly related to surfactant production or respiratory distress syndrome due to surfactant deficiency.

 

Option D. Bronchial mucosal epithelial cells: Incorrect because these cells line the bronchial passages and are primarily involved in mucous production and the removal of particulates and pathogens from inhaled air. They are not involved in surfactant production.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Respiratory distress syndrome, especially in premature infants, is commonly due to insufficient surfactant production by Type 2 pneumocytes. This deficiency impedes the lungs' ability to expand properly, leading to respiratory distress. Management often includes the administration of exogenous surfactant and supportive care to enhance lung function until the infant's own cells can produce adequate surfactant.

questions.text: Boundaries of Calot triangle are formed by all except? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Gall bladder

 

The gallbladder itself does not form a boundary of Calot's triangle. Instead, it's closely related to the triangle, being situated just adjacent to it.

 

It's an important landmark in cholecystectomy (surgical removal of the gallbladder) because of the structures that it contains. The identification of this triangle helps to prevent injury to the common bile duct during surgery.

 

  • Boundaries of Calot's triangle is bounded:
    • Medially/Left side - Common hepatic duct
    • Right side/ Laterally   Cystic duct
    • Superior - lower surface of liver
    • Contents of calot’s triangle - Cystic artery and lymph node of lund 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Common hepatic duct: This forms the inferior boundary of Calot's triangle. The common hepatic duct is the duct formed by the joining of the left and right hepatic ducts. It later joins the cystic duct to form the common bile duct.

 

Option B. Cystic duct: This duct connects the gallbladder to the common hepatic duct and subsequently forms the common bile duct. The cystic duct forms the lateral boundary of Calot's triangle.

 

Option C. Cystic artery: Inferior surface of liver forms the superior boundary of calot’s triangle

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hepatocystic triangle and triangle of Calot - Hepatocystic triangle (blue): Upper boundary of hepatocystic triangle is the inferior border of liver. Lateral, the cystic duct and the neck of the gallbladder. Medial, the common hepatic duct.

questions.text: What is the recommended target preductal oxygen saturation (SpO₂) for neonates at 5 minutes after birth according to the Neonatal Resuscitation Program (NRP) 2010 guidelines? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Ans: C. 80-85%

 

Explanation: 

 

According to the Neonatal Resuscitation Program (NRP) guidelines, the target preductal oxygen saturation (SpO₂) in neonates at 5 minutes after birth is 80-85%. This is part of the gradual progression of normal oxygen saturation values in the first 10 minutes after birth. The preductal SpO₂ is measured in the right upper limb (right hand).

 

The normal SpO₂ progression after birth is:

 

  • At 1 minute: 60-65%
  • At 2 minutes: 65-70%
  • At 3 minutes: 70-75%
  • At 4 minutes: 75-80%
  • At 5 minutes: 80-85%
  • At 10 minutes: 85-95%

 

To remember-

 

  • Start from 60
  • THEN ADD 5 for every minute till 5 minutes, only for the last 10 minutes - add 10
  • These targets acknowledge the normal physiological transition from fetal to neonatal circulation, where saturation gradually increases as the lungs expand and the pulmonary vascular resistance decreases.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 70-75% - This is the target SpO₂ at 3 minutes after birth, not at 5 minutes.

 

Option B. 75-80% - This is the target SpO₂ at 4 minutes after birth, not at 5 minutes.

 

Option D. 85-95% - This is the target SpO₂ at 10 minutes after birth, not at 5 minutes.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

The normal physiologic transition after birth involves a gradual increase in oxygen saturation, with a target SpO₂ of 80-85% at 5 minutes of life. These targeted ranges guide oxygen therapy during neonatal resuscitation to avoid both hypoxemia and hyperoxemia.

questions.text: Which of the following nerves is preferred in anesthesia to monitor neuromuscular blockade? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Ulnar Nerve

 

  • The ulnar nerve is the most commonly used nerve for monitoring neuromuscular blockade in the clinical setting.
  • By stimulating this nerve, we can observe the twitch response of the adductor pollicis muscle in the hand, which is representative of deeper muscles like the diaphragm and laryngeal muscles.
  • The ulnar nerve is easily accessible and provides consistent responses.

 

Why it's preferred:

 

  • Neuromuscular monitoring aims to ensure that patients have adequate muscle paralysis during surgery and complete recovery from paralysis before waking up.
  • The ulnar nerve-adductor pollicis muscle combination has a similar sensitivity to neuromuscular blocking drugs as the diaphragm and laryngeal muscles, which are critical for breathing and airway protection.
  • Using a Train of Four monitor or peripheral nerve stimulator, the ulnar nerve is stimulated to observe the twitch response, allowing anesthesiologists to gauge the depth of neuromuscular blockade and adjust drug dosages accordingly.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Median Nerve: The median nerve is less commonly used for neuromuscular monitoring because it does not provide as consistent or reliable a response as the ulnar nerve. The muscle response to stimulation of the median nerve may not accurately reflect the status of deeper muscles.

 

Option C. Radial Nerve: The radial nerve innervates muscles that primarily affect the extension of the wrist and fingers. While it can be used for monitoring, it is not the preferred choice because it is less sensitive to neuromuscular blocking agents compared to the ulnar nerve.

 

Option D. Mandibular Nerve: The mandibular nerve is not used for monitoring neuromuscular blockade in the clinical setting. It is part of the trigeminal nerve (cranial nerve V) and does not provide a useful twitch response for assessing neuromuscular blockade.

 

Educational Objective :

 

  • The ulnar nerve is the preferred nerve for monitoring neuromuscular blockade in anesthesia due to its accessibility and reliable twitch response of the adductor pollicis muscle, which reflects the status of critical muscles like the diaphragm and laryngeal muscles.

 

Ref: Miller’s Anesthesia, 9th Ed. Pg 834

questions.text: Recommended sequence of premedication during elective intubation in a neonate is: (NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Atropine > Fentanyl > Vecuronium

 

In neonatal intubation, the correct sequence starts with atropine to prevent bradycardia, which is especially important in neonates who are particularly sensitive to vagal stimulation during laryngoscopy. Bradycardia is the most common adverse cardiac event during the perioperative period in pediatric patients. Following atropine, fentanyl (a short-acting opioid) provides analgesia and some sedation, and finally vecuronium (a non-depolarizing muscle relaxant) facilitates intubation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In neonatal intubation, always administer atropine first to prevent bradycardia, followed by analgesic medication (fentanyl), and only then a muscle relaxant (vecuronium) - this sequence protects cardiovascular stability while ensuring adequate analgesia before paralysis.

questions.text: An unimmunized 2-year-old child presented with coryza, conjunctivitis, and bluish-white spots in his buccal mucosa near the lower molar teeth. A day later, he developed a maculopapular rash on the face and neck. What is the nature of the causative virus? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Enveloped ss RNA

 

The given clinical vignette is suggestive of measles. Measles virus is a Paramyxovirus which is an enveloped, single-stranded RNA (S RNA) virus.

 

The onset of rashes after the development of Koplik spots that are small, bluish-white ulcerations on the inner aspect of the cheek at the level of premolars, with associated features of coryza, and conjunctivitis is suggestive of measles.

 

Measles: The virus has an incubation period of 8-12 days, after which the prodrome phase begins with mild fever, conjunctivitis, upper respiratory tract infection, and pathognomic Koplik spots. This is followed by the appearance of maculopapular rash after 4th day of fever, which begins at the face and spreads to the torso and extremities. Lymphadenopathy may be present. Patients can transmit infection 3 days before and 4-6 days after the onset of rash.

 

Warthin-Finkeldey giant cells are pathognomonic of measles. These are multinucleated giant cells formed by the fusion of infected cells.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Naked ss RNA: Incorrect because the measles virus is enveloped.

 

Option C. Naked ds RNA: No human viruses are known with a naked dsRNA genome.

 

Option D. Enveloped ds RNA: This combination does not apply to human pathogens in the context given (measles virus is ssRNA).

 

Educational Objective:

 

Measles virus is characterized as an enveloped single-stranded RNA virus, notable for the unique clinical presentation of Koplik's spots, which precede the characteristic maculopapular rash. This distinguishing feature is essential for the clinical diagnosis of measles.
